nodes.userMessage: Hey... I need to talk. I just bombed an important job interview and I feel like such a failure.

choices.text: I'm sorry to hear that. Failing an interview is always tough. Do you want to tell me what happened?
A failed interview isn't the end of the world. There will be others.

nodes.userMessage: I completely panicked when they asked me a technical question. My brain just froze and I stumbled for like 5 minutes...

choices.text: Next time, you should prepare better for technical questions. That's often what makes the difference.
Stress can really paralyze us in those moments. It's a normal reaction, not a sign of incompetence.

nodes.userMessage: Easy for you to say... It was my dream job. I spent weeks preparing.

choices.text: You're right, I understand it meant a lot to you. Tell me what happened.
If you prepared so well, why didn't it work out then?

nodes.userMessage: Thanks... The worst part is I knew the answer. I figured it out 10 minutes after I left. I'm so mad at myself.

choices.text: That's too bad. Maybe you should have asked for a few seconds to think instead of panicking.
That's frustrating, but it actually proves you have the skills. Stress just temporarily blocked access to them.

nodes.userMessage: I did prepare! I studied for hours. But in the moment, everything just went blank...

choices.text: Technical preparation doesn't always protect against stress. Have you ever tried breathing techniques or visualization?
Maybe you put too much pressure on yourself. You need to learn to put things in perspective.

nodes.userMessage: ... Wow. Thanks for the support.
You really think so? Sometimes I feel like an impostor. Like I don't deserve these opportunities.

choices.text: If you doubt yourself that much, maybe you're not ready for this type of position yet.
What you're describing sounds like impostor syndrome. It's very common, especially among competent people who are hard on themselves.

nodes.userMessage: I know I put too much pressure on myself. But I can't help it. I've always been like this.

choices.text: It's a hard tendency to change, but not impossible. Have you ever considered talking to a professional about it?
At some point, you need to detach from the outcome and accept that you can't control everything.

nodes.userMessage: No, never tried that. Do you think it could help?

choices.text: Yes, many people find it helpful. For example, taking 3 deep breaths before answering can help calm your nervous system.
It depends on the person. Some find it useless. You could always try.

nodes.userMessage: Impostor syndrome... I've heard of it. But how do you get over it?

choices.text: It's a long-term process. You'd probably need to see a therapist to work through it properly.
A first step is to write down your concrete achievements. When doubt creeps in, you can reread that list to remind yourself of your real skills.

nodes.userMessage: ... You know what, I regret asking. Bye.
A therapist? I don't know... I feel like that's for people with real problems.

choices.text: Seeing a therapist isn't just for severe cases. It's also for understanding yourself better and developing tools to manage stress.
If you don't feel ready, you could also try meditation apps or books on the subject.

nodes.userMessage: Yeah, I know. It's just hard to apply when you're in the moment.

choices.text: That's true. That's why it takes practice. Every small step counts.
With time, it becomes more natural. The important thing is not to give up.

nodes.userMessage: Ok, I'll try that. And about the failed interview, do you think I should reach out to them?

choices.text: Honestly, if the interview went badly, it might be better to move on and look elsewhere.
You could send a thank-you email mentioning your motivation. It shows professionalism and leaves a good impression.

nodes.userMessage: That's a good idea. I'll start doing that. Thanks, it really helps talking to you.

choices.text: You're welcome. Good luck with everything.
I'm glad I could help. Don't hesitate to come back if you need to talk. You've got this!

nodes.userMessage: Ok, I'll think about it. Thanks anyway for the advice.
Maybe you're right. I'll look into it. Thanks for listening.

choices.text: It's brave of you to consider it. I really wish you the best going forward.
No problem. I hope things get better.

nodes.userMessage: Thanks. It feels good to talk about it. I feel a little less alone with all this.

choices.text: You're really not alone. Many people go through the same doubts. And you can always come back to talk.
Glad I could help. Take care!

nodes.userMessage: You're right, I'll do that! It can't hurt to try. Thanks for everything!

choices.text: Good luck! I hope it works out.
Exactly! And whatever happens, you'll have learned from this experience. I believe in you.

nodes.userMessage: Hmm... That's kind of defeatist advice, isn't it?

choices.text: You're right, I expressed myself poorly. If it really matters to you, go for the thank-you email. You never know!
I'm just being realistic. Sometimes you need to know when to turn the page.

nodes.userMessage: Thank you so much! ðŸ’™ This conversation really helped. Talk soon!
Thanks. See you.
Ok, I'll do it then. Thanks for taking the time to listen!
Ok... Well, thanks anyway. Bye.
